List of Pixhawk 2.1 issues. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7618

 - I2C driver issues. I2C2 is the px4fmu-v2_default onboard bus. This causes problems for certain i2c drivers expecting I2C magnetometers to be external, or not even trying onboard.

   - likely many other I2C drivers
 - secondary power brick not fully supported. I think this is in place of servo valid

title: Syslink can't handle >30 byte Mavlink messages?
body:
New to Crazyflie, I have a 2.0 file and I've been trying to get Mavlink messages over Crazyflie PA for a few days.
Here's what I found via trial and error:
1. messages <= 28 bytes are transmitted flawlessly (e.g. SYSTEM_TIME, SERVO_OUTPUT_RAW, ATTITUDE)
2. messages >=31 bytes are received as random garbage (e.g. HIGHRES_IMU, ALTITUDE:
sysid:1 compid:1 time_usec:72506465346777910 altitude_monotonic:-1.045921E38 altitude_amsl:2.3803417E-38 altitude_local:-7.7662487E37 altitude_relative:2.3804148E-38 altitude_terrain:2.3693253E-38 bottom_clearance:1.2066013E-23')

Sending end is PX4 latest master running on Crazyflie2, receiving end is a Java program listening on port 14550, using DatagramSocket receiving DatagramPacket 1024 bytes at a time, and parsed with Mavlink generated java library, using PX4's v2.0/common.xml, protocol version 1.0.

I am guessing it's a syslink issue because when I run PX4 on simulator, all messages are received correctly, and simulator it does not go through Syslink.

I've been banging my head for a few days, any help would be highly appreciated!

title: MPU9250 Reset reorganization (fixes I2C functionality)

milestone.title: Release v1.7.0
milestone.description: Maintenance release of the 1.7.0 release schedule.

body:
During MPU9250 initialization, depending on passthrough modes, the main chip must be reset() before the magnetometer connection is initialized in order to setup the passthrough to the magnetometer.

Current sequence of events (during init):
---
...
- reset()
    - "MPU6050" reset
    - AK8963 reset <- fails because not yet connected
- Magnetometer init/connect

...

Fixed sequence:
---
...
- reset_mpu()
    - "MPU6050" reset
- magnetometer init
- ak8963_reset()
    - AK8963 reset

...

The functionality of `reset()` is preserved, but for the initialization phase, the reset is split into a two phase reset.

Fixes #7624


Also adds a one liner fix specified in another issue report.

title: `EKF GPS fusion timeout` errors with good GPS data available lead to big position estimate jumps
body:
While flying an octo with ublox M8T GPS we see rapid extreme position estimate jumps, as logged here:

http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=d6944989-20ef-4007-bf1e-ca0b3732347f

- Multiple warnings are logged similar to: `2:24:865 | WARNING | [lib__ecl] EKF GPS fusion timeout - reset to GPS`
- Have tried two different GPS units (ublox M8N, M8T) on several different airframes with the same results.
- Looking at the code it appears this warning shows up when ECL decides GPS data is now valid after having been invalid for some time. From what I can tell from the logs, a good GPS position was continuously available during operation. 
- This problem has not yet appeared using the UAVCAN Zubax GNSS2 (which does not use the ubx gps driver.)

Possibly related to:
- https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6443
- http://discuss.px4.io/t/position-estimate-problem-in-flight/3162/4

title: BUG: Code dependent on the compiler
body:
Hey there.

I've been trying to run the SITL version on a rpi3 and when compiling with the arm-linux-gnueabihf-raspbian toolchain the simulation was not running correctly.

After a few days of hunting the bug down, I found that, when not defining a CAL_MAGX_ROT, it's value is left at -1, and this value is then cast to the Rotation enum, which starts at 0. This causes undefined and problematic behavior, especially with the aforementioned toolchain. It caused the rot matrix return to be different than expected, mag report values to drift, causing an increase in the innovation value of the ekf2 loop and signaling a fusion timeout, causing the estimated position to jump all over.

I understand that this behavior might not show up when the config file is properly done, or when working with a full fledged ground control software, or with the specific native toolchain, but in my bare boned setup where I'm developing an offboard controller and a ground control of my own, it makes a difference. For me I just set the defaults of all the CAL_MAGX_ROT to 0 on ~/src/Firmware/src/modules/sensors/sensor_params.c, but a more appropriate fix could be made for the official repo.

I've also been able to replicate the problem when compiling with gcc and running it on fc24.x86_64, mainly when printing several times in what should have been quick loops.

Don't know if anybody will see this, but from my perspective code should never be dependent on the used compiler.

PS: I'm a new developer and I'm sorry if I missed anything that would make this bug report useless. From my perspective, opening the issue seemed the right thing to do

title: PX4 1.6.3: Constant "High Airpseed" errors.
body:
Hello guys,

Here is another issue we have since 1.6.0 RC1. We constantly have problems calibrating the airspeed sensor. It does not matter which airspeed sensor we use. 

But depsite that once calibrated the airspeed stays at ~0 m/s The moment we restart the Pixhawk and connect again to the QGC we get High Airspeed error and a RED light and not able to arm. Then we check in the Fly view that the airspeed stays at ~0 m/s. Then we produce airflow in the pitot for about 1-2 seconds and the RED light disapears and it becomes Blue Hearbeat. We are able to arm without a problem. 

It seems to us that by blowing in the pitot we remove the high airspeed error. 

We can reproduce everytime.

Currently using HKPilot32 + FMUv2 1.6.3 and MS4525 sesnor for the tests.

This High Airspeed errors are really annoying. Especially if there is no high airspeed measured.

title: PX4 1.6.3: Strange problem with Airspeed-less transition.
body:
We were flying 1.6.3 for some time. But recently decided to reset all the parameters with the new defaults. For this we use change of air-frame procedure. So we carefully introduced our PIDs on top of the new defaults. We removed the circuit breaker for the airspeed and thus it did not ask us to calibrate the airspeed so the diff press cal params were empty 0.00. 

In this setup we were not able to complete the transition. It never stopped the quad despite the speed got exceeding 20 m/s and the transition continued forever up to the crash.

http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=b6653ab1-ada7-4711-abaf-00a6a51249dc

Because we flew the 1.6.3 airspeed-less without a problem we just started thinking. We enabled the airspeed. Calibrated the airpseed. Then again we disconnected it from the breaker.

On the Bench test perfect transitions.

http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=619b0b6b-ae84-4220-aa52-73ddce2b7fcc

http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=3647be91-b6f2-4be1-a5a3-f66ca93c8b94

Also we flew without airspeed without any problem. So the only thing we had to do was to calibrate the airspeed in order to make the transition in aispeed-less config.

During this tests we discovered another thing. In airspeed-less mode the only way we could manage the transition is timing. 

There is a parameter VT_F_TR_OL_TM which is supposed to guarantee fixed transition time without airspeed. But in reality in airspeed-less mode the transition is done now by the VT_TRANS_MIN_TM which is the minimum front transition time. The VT_F_TR_OL_TM did not have any effect over the transition timing.

title: [PixHawk3] Accel1 startup bias huge changes
body:
On my Drotek PixHawk Pro v1.3 I'm facing a strange behavior.
First I saw sometimes the warning "Accels inconsistent, check cal". After further investigations, I saw that usually, the Z-axis value is usually around 9.8m/s2, but sometimes, the value of the Acc1 is completely wrong (e.g.; 2 or 15). The value of the accelerometer 0 is always correct.

```TOPIC: sensor_accel instance 0 #1

timestamp: 11548976

integral_dt: 4000

error_count: 0

x: -0.0971

y:  0.0563

z:  9.8932

x_integral: -0.0003

y_integral:  0.0002

z_integral:  0.0391

temperature: 42.7938

range_m_s2: 78.4532

scaling:  0.0024

x_raw: 7

y_raw: 40

z_raw: 4074

temperature_raw: 5815

device_id: 3608074

```

```TOPIC: sensor_accel instance 1 #1

timestamp: 163650940

integral_dt: 4006

error_count: 0

x:  0.0778

y:  0.4095

z:  2.6501

x_integral:  0.0003

y_integral:  0.0014

z_integral:  0.0081

temperature: 59.1025

range_m_s2: 156.9064

scaling:  0.0048

x_raw: 53

y_raw: 29

z_raw: 480

temperature_raw: 8701

device_id: 1442826

```
After a few consecutive reboots on the pixhawk, I obtained the following sequence:
The behavior was the following: `first calibration` -> `-9.8` -> `reboot` -> `-15` -> `2nd calibration` -> `-9.8` -> `reboot` -> `-3` -> `3rd calibration` -> `-9.8` -> `reboot` -> `-15` -> `reboot` -> `*-9.8*` -> `reboot` -> `-15` -> `reboot` -> `-15` - `reboot 3x` -> `-9.8` -> `reboot` -> `-15` .........

I tried with two other new PixHawks Pro v3.1 and I can reproduce the error. However, strange thing, I tried on a v1.2 and I wasn't able to obtain the same result after more than 10 consecutive reboots.

Here is a log where the value is correct:
http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=170ce58a-794e-414d-8607-168ce8c734ef
And here, one with the incorrect bias:
http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=e0bba09b-1129-4438-8ded-baede72f24cc

The logs come from a device uncalibrated, but I had the same issue with an autopilot fully calibrated (thermal + scale&offset).

title: Flyaway after loss of datalink (v1.6.2)
body:
Hello,
Few days ago I flown my multicopter for about 1.5 km. and almost got flyaway, only using RC saved it for safe landing. 
I got 'ALL DAT LINK LOSS' and it seems that RTL has been engaged (I still had downlink). but, instead of flying toward home position for landing the multicopter started to fly very fast backward.
from the log I see that just after losing the datalink (at 10:28) it did got new heading, X and Y setpoints of home. but just after that (when the link was regained?) the position setpoint sets back to its current position, no change of heading setpoint. and the multicopter gets higher and higher pitch, that leads it to fly very fast backward, not closing the X and Y position setpoints. I have tried to send new commands reposition, pause the multicopter seems to be affected by them but still contiues to fly at very high speed.
At this point (2km away) we toke RC control, and fly it to home for landing.

title: Setting mode to PosCtl after RTL causes large velocity setpoint
body:
If you command an RTL then set mode to Manual PosCtl, the vehicle will take off very fast towards the home location with no stick input while in PosCtl.

SITL Log: http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=dd5b9854-3c7a-46ce-b97d-457dd3185a88
Replication steps: 
- Take off in PosCtl
- Command RTL
- Set mode to PosCtl
The vehicle will quickly ramp up to 9 m/s with no stick input then slow down after a few seconds
It's a lot clearer to see if you set all the VEL_MAX parameters to 3 m/s
So I set 
MPC_VEL_MAN_MAX = 3 m/s
MPC_XY_CRUISE = 3 m/s
MPC_XY_VEL_MAX = 3 m/s
You'll see the vehicle go very slowly at 3 m/s then when you set mode to POSCTL, it'll quickly shoot up to 8-9 m/s ground speed with no stick input.

A plot of the local_position vel_y and setpoint vel_y:
![rtl_posctl](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1168541/27511724-b062b2ec-58e8-11e7-97f6-0df27c27b3e2.png)
The crazy velocity setpoint gets generated right after setting the vehicle to Manual PosCtl.

title: Motor spinning on USB power reset

milestone.title: Release v1.7.0
milestone.description: Maintenance release of the 1.7.0 release schedule.

body:
Despite the fixes in #7123, we still get motors spinning on unplugging the USB cable.

**Steps to reproduce**:
1. Plug in battery, USB cable
2. Start QGroundControl
3. Unplug USB cable

It only happens if QGroundControl has been talking to the PX4, as this triggers USB telemetry boolean that actually makes the PX4 reset after USB has been unplugged.

I have looked at the PWM signal with an oscilloscope and have pictures of it, but they aren't very telling.

**Workaround:**
In `src/modules/commander/commander.cpp`, find the `usleep()` just before the reboot and put `board_on_reset(0);` *before* the sleep. This sets all PWMs to zero.

A better long term fix would be to add a sleep to the `board_on_reset`.

title: EKF2: GPS - vision fusion does not follow vision pose estimation
body:
From a couple of months I am using a drone with Pixhawk and an onboard computer. Till now I had very few problems.
I was using LPE  to fuse GPS and vision pose (this is working really fine), but I wanted to try the EKF2.

I flashed, from QGroundControl, the latest stable version 1.6.2 on my pixhawk.
* I set 
   * EK2_EVP_NOISE to the minimum value (0.01m) 
   * EKF2_GPS_P_NOISE to an high value (5.0m)
   * EK2_AID_MASK to 9 (GPS and vision pose enable)
   * EK2_HGT_MODE to vision
* I am sending the vision estimate to the topic /mavros/vision_pose/pose.

I tried this configuration in an environment with a not really good GPS signal, so even if the drone is not moving, the local state estimate is moving of several meters.
What I want is that, whenever I have a pose from vision, the state estimate follows it instead of the GPS.

I did several experiments with the drone fixed, and the outcome was always a state estimate that follow the vision estimate in Z but the GPS in X and Y.
If I disable the GPS on the EK2_AID_MASK then the state estimate follows the vision pose (as you can see in the first plot), but as soon as I re-enable the GPS then the vision pose is not trusted anymore (second plot).  

![outside_gps_vision2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7209483/27083862-3c273ebc-504a-11e7-962b-f4369b163203.png)
* second -52 activate vision pose
* second -22 disable GPS in EK2_AID_MASK

![outside_gps_vision3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7209483/27083875-48f2b6d0-504a-11e7-8c6a-d1f4905ca86f.png)
* second -90 enable GPS in EK2_AID_MASK

I am sure that the vision pose arrives and is listened by the filter, so it sounds to me a problem of covariances, but I really tried a lot of setups with the same result:
 - sending /mavros/vision_pose/pos_cov with tiny covariances
 - make the GPS covariance even bigger
 - put the vision pose covariance to 0 (kind of stupid)

Am I missing something? 
Some parameters to set in order to make the vision trusted more (as with EK2_HGT_MODE for the Z coordinate)?

title: 1.6.2 VTOL RTL does not trigger back-transition
body:
I think that this commit breaks the back-transition when RTL is commanded to a VTOL drone:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/7249

However I'm not 100% sure since my drone doesn't work with master or stable. @dagar suggested that this could easily be tested in SITL, although I don't have that setup at the moment. I would appreciate it if someone can verify this with SITL.

title: PX4 1.6.1: Land detector did not disarm after land in mission VTOL
body:
Hello,

We made a mission without RC control only with the QGC. We used version 3.1.3. Everithing went ok except the land detector did not disarm after the mission was complete and the VTOL was landed. The only way we could disarm with 3.1.3 was emergency stop.

VTOL left on the ground with spinning motors for some time.

Here is the log:
http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=971f681b-2e49-4e67-816f-5b3b9c52a817

Also in Position or Altitude modes we have the same problem. The land detector probably is working, because when we touch down in one of Alt and Pos Modes the QGC says we have to be either in manual mode or landed in order to disarm.

I saw it is very easy in QGC 3.2 to disarm. But it is still very nice if in the case of mission and Guided modes after touch down the land detector could at least disarm in 10-20 seconds.

title: 1.6.1 : No transition on SD CARD missing.
body: I dont know if it is VTOL problem but we tried it with VTOL. On SD CARD missing there was no sound or indication for the missing card. Also we were able to arm and fly the VTOL in MC mode without any problems. But then it did not allow us to transition in FW flight without the SD CARD. Also there was no indication in QGC about the missing card, nor there was a sound form the Pixhawk.

title: Initialize Error calling the uorb fastrpc initalize method..
body:
I switched up to 3.1.3 Snapdragon Flight image  and v1.6.2 of PX4. Built PX4 with `make eagle_legacy_default`. What's going on here?

Mind the large error dump:
> px4 starting.
>

MS5611 sudden temperature and/or pressure jumps
body:
Hello,

I'm experiencing sudden jumps in temperature and/or pressure jumps on RPIv3 + Navio2.
It looks like that from time to time, the read value for temperature is 0, in which case the next value to be read will be invalid (pressure). The same applies for pressure reading, if it is zero, the next reading (temperature), will be invalid.
Since a sample is composed of a temperature & pressure reading, in the worst case, when pressure is zero, we will miss two samples.

Example of bad samples:
Bad pressure leads to bad temperature:
(t,p) (8471480, 0)
(t,p) (6519328, 8879896)
18378647 18377494 ms5611 temp, alt (-31.240000, 1461.988525, 84951.000000)
(t,p) (8471576, 8879736)
(t,p) (8471448, 8879832)

Bad temperature leads to bad pressure:
(t,p) (8474264, 8880024)
(t,p) (0, 5261664)
122574877 122573726 ms5611 temp, alt (-250.660004, nan, -12514.000000)
(t,p) (8474360, 8880056)
(t,p) (8474136, 8879928)

I've addressed this here https://github.com/PX4/DriverFramework/pull/198

Yaw/thrust saturation and loss of control during flight
body:
Hi everyone,

During a position control flight with my VTOL (in MC mode only), I encountered a really strange behavior. After flying perfectly well, the yaw control was suddenly lost and the drone was loosing altitude.

![esc_response2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14822839/26549616/2bc1ae62-447a-11e7-81eb-4d79c5c93205.png)

As you can see, around t=59s, the drone did not respond to the yaw command even if the ESC reported acceleration and deceleration of the motors. After that between t=63s and t=69s, the drone is spinning around it's yaw axis and since it was loosing altitude, the thrust did reach saturation, without any RPM response.

I'm suspecting a mixer saturation or an ESC issue. 

Link to the complete [log](http://logs.px4.io/plot_app?log=55960095-7efd-4e28-8acc-1854828e75bc).

Finally, my setup is a PixHawk Pro with Orel 20 ESCs and a mRo GPS.

title: Air frame init script files attempt to set rates that will fails on all FMU PWM
body:
There are 2 issue:
1. Air frame init script files attempt to set rates that will fails on all FMU
2. Need a way to set the default rate uses when an alt rates is applied.

## Issue 1:
Air frame script 
```set PWM_OUT 5```

Later command
```pwm rate -c ${PWM_OUT} -r ${PWM_RATE}```

FMUv2 HW: default is /dev/pwm_output0
```
channel group 0: channels 1 2
channel group 1: channels 5 6 7 8
channel group 2: channels 3 4
```
2) FMUv4 HW: default is /dev/pwm_output0
```
channel group 0: channels 1 2 3 4
channel group 1: channels 5 6
```

FMUv2
```
nsh>  pwm rate -c 5 -r 400
ERROR [pwm] PWM_SERVO_SET_SELECT_UPDATE_RATE
```
It would have to be ```pwm rate -c 5678 -r 400``` On V2

FMUv4
```
pwm rate -c 5 -r 400
WARN  [fmu] rate group 1 mask 30 bad overlap 10
ERROR [pwm] PWM_SERVO_SET_SELECT_UPDATE_RATE
```
It would have to be ```pwm rate -c 56 -r 400``` On V4


## Issue 2:
Assuming FMUv2 or FMUv4
```pwm rate -g 0 -r 400``` Sets group 0 to ```alternative``` rate of 400 Hz and ALL other groups to ```default rate``` 50 Hz
```pwm rate -g 1 -r 25``` Sets group 1 to ```alternative``` rate of 25 Hz and ALL other groups to ```default rate``` 50. Thus undoing the Group 0 rate of 400.

title: ubx checksum err

milestone.title: Release v1.6.0
milestone.description: The main novelty of this release is a massive NuttX update adding support for STM32F7 and fault logging.

body:
During normal startup or reboot I sometimes get `WARN [gps] ubx checksum err` followed by `WARN [gps] GPS module lost`. I did a test where I set a test point when the warning happens and connected the serial lines of the GPS to an oscilloscope with serial analyzer function.
What I see is that the error immediately occurs after the configuration of the gps module (function GPS
DriverUBX::configure).
At the end of the function the message MON_VER is polled but there is no wait for the answer. This should not be a problem and the answer is handled with the next “receive” in the main loop. As the answer of the MON_VER is long (payload 190 bytes), it seems that in this case the input buffer overflows (GPS_READ_BUFFER_SIZE = 128 Bytes) and some bytes of the MON_VER answer get lost. Therefore the ubx decoder of the FMU reads the beginning of the next NAV_PVT as pay load of MON_VER and the checksum is wrong. I think maybe this problem occurs only with newer ubx modules (ublox M8N) as the output of MON_VER is now longer. 
![ubx_crc_err](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18105084/25616957/fb549540-2f3f-11e7-9226-e0ef89e3a61d.png)

title: Potentially infinite and deleted loops found by PVS-Studio
body:
Hello,
I have found and fixed bug using PVS-Studio tool. PVS-Studio is a static code analyzer for C, C++ and C#: https://www.viva64.com/en/pvs-studio/

Analyzer warning:

* [V712](https://www.viva64.com/en/w/V712/) Be advised that compiler may delete this cycle or make it infinity. Use volatile variable(s) or synchronization primitives to avoid this. [src/platforms/posix/main.cpp 519](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/platforms/posix/main.cpp#L519), [603](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/platforms/posix/main.cpp#L603)
* [V712](https://www.viva64.com/en/w/V712/) Be advised that compiler may delete this cycle or make it infinity. Use volatile variable(s) or synchronization primitives to avoid this. [src/drivers/device/vdev_posix.cpp 281](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/drivers/device/vdev_posix.cpp#L281)

In addition, I suggest having a look at the emails, sent from @pvs-studio.com.

Best regards,
Phillip Khandeliants

title: Master fix pwm

milestone.title: Release v1.6.0
milestone.description: The main novelty of this release is a massive NuttX update adding support for STM32F7 and fault logging.

body:
- fmu:Fixes cause of 0 values reported in pwm info

   The root cause was the replacement of a local variable num_outputs
   with the class member _num_outputs.
   The effect of a "bad mix" is to return 0 - this clamped the
   _num_outputs to 0.

   Prior to commit  3b3e2b2 px4fmu: "consolidate usage of output mode"
   this would not have  been an issue because the local num_outputs
   was reset every cycle"

  As a secondary issue. We should call up_pwm_servo_init() to
  establish the PWM channel allocation early. This then allows
  FMU::set_pwm_rate to properly check for improper rate request
  not isolate to one group (timer).

- 2101_fw_AERT:Fix mask to be all channels used
  This was the root cause of the rate group 0 mask F bad overlap 8
  message.

 ***N.B. All mix files need to be vetted.***

- oneshot:trigger exit early in no chan in oneshot
  
  this is just an optimization

title: px4fmu_V2 upgrade issue: nsh: vmount: command not found

milestone.title: Release v1.6.0
milestone.description: The main novelty of this release is a massive NuttX update adding support for STM32F7 and fault logging.

body:
When I upgrade the firmware on my Pixhawk v2 to the latest bits (sync'd today), clean clone, & build of master branch, make px4fmu-v2_default, I get the following boot error:
```
ERROR [param] Parameter MNT_MODE_IN not found
nsh: vmount: command not found
```
This happens on multiple pixhawks.  If I go back to latest stable build using QGroundControl then it boots fine.

Curiously if I add the drivers/vmount driver in the cmake/configs/nuttx_px4fmu-v2_default.cmake, then it boots fine.  So what do I need to do to make it boot without this driver since it is supposed to be commented out now... ?

body:
Being in ALTHOLD and trying to keep the quad at the same position manually (latest master, PixRacer, LPE)  at about 1m for several seconds, the quad shoots up in the air, without any further response to the sticks. To avoid further climb, I had to switch off by the kill switch causing the vehicle to crash, which disconnected power. Although log should have been written to log004.ulg, it has not been stored on SD - so unfortunately no log is available, but messages were written to disc:

title: Possible Bug in HIL_STATE_QUATERNION handling
body:
Hi,
@TSC21 and I are developing HIL plugins in MAVROS. This is to allow any ROS-compatible simulator to be used in HIL setup.

In the decoding of HIL_STATE_QUATERNION msg, in PX4 firmware, specifically the ```vehicle_global_position```,
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ecb2511a7bbad094bff23dd95036eda0656778f0/src/modules/simulator/simulator_mavlink.cpp#L402-L413
altitude is divided by ```1E3```, but ```lat/lon``` are not scaled down properly. In the msg definition,
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/912ed98a28022504ef3ec4bf1bce0fe041f83ac4/msg/vehicle_global_position.msg

```lat/lon/alt``` are assumed to be in deg/deg/meters. And, they are supposed to be received in deg 1E7 and meters 1E3 according to 
https://pixhawk.ethz.ch/mavlink/#HIL_STATE_QUATERNION

So, I guess that 
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ecb2511a7bbad094bff23dd95036eda0656778f0/src/modules/simulator/simulator_mavlink.cpp#L407-L408
should be divided by 1E7.

Also the ```vehicle_global_position``` msg does not have ```timestamp``` field,

So, possibly another mistake here,
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/ecb2511a7bbad094bff23dd95036eda0656778f0/src/modules/simulator/simulator_mavlink.cpp#L404

Thanks.

title: Why I couldn't change flight mode to 'position control' or  'auto hold' when using LPE?
body:
I am working on testing LPE with px4flow.
I uploaded px4fmu-v2_lpe target and followed the instruction in #6864 to set the params in QGC. I set SYS_MC_EST_GROUP to LPE and LPE_FUSION to 162.
I did a flight test, I took off with Stabilized mode and turned to Altitude mode. The flight can keep the same hight but slowly flew away. Is it normal to act like this?
Then I wanted to try position mode and hold mode, but when I set them in QGC I got the warnings 'reject position control' and 'reject auto hold'. Why did this happen? Did I use the right flight mode for the px4flow test?

title: FTP read file timeouts
body:
I cannot reliably read a file from px4 log directory using mavlink ftp get command.  I get a few packets, then nothing, even with a retry.  Same from QGC.  So I was playing around and found that if I recompile mavlink_ftp.cpp with the conditional flag "MAVLINK_FTP_DEBUG" enabled, then it works perfectly.... so its a weird Heisenberg uncertainty bug... try to watch it and it goes away...

I'm using Pixhawk (px4fmu_v2_default).

title: Failsafe mode on while in OFFBOARD mode
body:
Hi,

I've recently encountered some problem while using **OFFBOARD** mode. I'm using **px4** firmware with **MAVROS**.

I've been developing some algorithms for autonomous flying. I'm using basically code from [this](https://dev.px4.io/ros-mavros-offboard.html) documentation. Some time ago there was no problem. But recently I've seen my copter loosing connection or something like that.

Here's example of my log during flight:

The message from **px4** firmware tells me that there's no **OFFBOARD** but at the same time when I check state from **MAVROS**, it says there is **OFFBOARD**. The copter then goes to **failsafe** mode and back again to **OFFBOARD** control which messes with overall control.

So I have no idea what's going on and if it's my fault or not. Has anybody any idea?

Thank you for any advice.

title: Camera Trigger

milestone.title: Release v1.6.0
milestone.description: The main novelty of this release is a massive NuttX update adding support for STM32F7 and fault logging.

body:
There are several outstanding issues with the camera trigger which might be causing very weird and hard-to-track problems due to direct hardware access.

1. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6689 *[Could not reproduce]*
> Scenario on Pixhawk hardware:
> 
> Select Trigger mode "Time based always on"
> Select Triggrer interface "MAVLINK ..."
> After powercycle the autopilot does not boot.
> Only workaround I found is to flash it with Ardupilot and then back to PX4.
> 
> Reproducable on master@3961c46

2. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6839 **[Fixed]**
> For some reason the trigger is not activated.
> 
> In the QGC section for camera, it was by default set as PWM emitted on port AUX 5 and 6.
> Considering I was need just 1 port (the NEX camera is activated by IR sensor, which work with PWM) to trigger the camera, I disabled the AUX5 and let the AUX6 on. For some reason the AUX6 has never emitted a signal during the whole flight, and the log confirm, nothing came out on port AUX6.

3. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6839
> Any chance to set a PWM output for triggering a camera on an MAIN port instead of AUX to make it work?

4. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6703 **[Fixed]**
> Configured PX4 on Pixhawk to do Time based trigger always on with:
> TRIG_ACT_TIME: 500ms
> TRIG_INTERVAL: 1000ms
> TRIG_PINS: 123456
> Expected to have equal PWM outputs on all 6 AUX ports.
> This is what I get:
> With RC transmitter ON:
> AUX1: constant 1500 regardless of what is configured in Radio setup.
> AUX2: constant 1500 regardless of what is configured in Radio setup.
> AUX3: constant 1500 regardless of what is configured in Radio setup.
> AUX4: constant 1500 regardless of what is configured in Radio setup.
> AUX5: No signal
> AUX6: No signal
> With RC transmitter OFF:
> AUX1: 1500 for 0.5s, 1700 for 0.5s (expected behavior)
> AUX2: constant 1500
> AUX3: 1500 for 0.5s, 1700 for 0.5s (expected behavior)
> AUX4: constant 1500
> AUX5: No signal
> AUX6: No signal
> 
> Turns out that I can get camera trigger working only while RC is turned OFF and only on two pins which does not make sense.

5. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6092 **[Fixed]**
> I've been testing the camera trigger and haven't got it working on Pins 5&6 of the FMU (TRIG_PINS = 56). I've also tried the setting TRIG_PINS = 34 which works fine.
> I'm wondering if there was a bug introduced somewhere because the default pins are in fact 5,6.

6. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/4941 **[Fixed]**
> The current approach of accessing PWM pins directly is suboptimal as it can conflict with the FMU driver's management of GPIO and PWM outputs. It would be good to coordinate on how to properly layer this.

7. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/5437 **[Fixed]**

8. https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/5530 **[Fixed]**

The driver needs to ACK the TRIGGER_CONTROL command so that mavros knows the call succeeded.

title: PX4FLOW LPE not working: Z is reversed
body:
I am trying to get a stable position estimation using only PX4FLOW but it looks like the Z axis is reversed. 
"M1:OPTICAL_FLOW_RAD.distance" is very stable around 1 m (based on sonar)
"M1:LOCAL_POSITION_NED.z" variation is reversed relative to "M1:OPTICAL_FLOW_RAD.distance". See the graph below.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15964070/24583839/f5816f44-170c-11e7-96a9-72ecb1f8f061.png)

M1:OPTICAL_FLOW_RAD.quality is around 250
LPE_FUSION is 162
I also tried LPE_FUSION = 34 (no baro) and "M1:LOCAL_POSITION_NED.z" stays close to zero.
Firmware version 1.6.0 rc
See also parameters file attached
[PX4_param_4-1_params.txt](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/files/888152/PX4_param_4-1_params.txt)
